fields.additionalinformation:
Potential new client is calling concerning a property damage. States there was a house fire. Please call back.

What type of matter are you calling about? Property damage

Date of Loss/Damage: 12/6/24

What City/State are you located in? KY, Colby Port

How did you hear about us?: Referred by friend (BRANDI) 

Client experienced a house fire. Her insurer, Nationwide, conducted an investigation and even suggested possible litigation against the receptacle manufacturer, claiming a product defect. Nationwide has paid approximately $137,000–$150,000 toward the dwelling and only about $30,000 of the $140,000 personal property limit. Jamie has been unable to get contractors to provide repair estimates due to the rural location and her overnight work schedule, and she ultimately purchased another home because of the delays. She reports significant issues with how Nationwide handled her personal property claim—although she completed an in-person inventory with an adjuster, another representative later changed item conditions without seeing them and questioned whether Jamie’s income supported owning newer items. Nationwide also denied several fire-damaged items while claiming an inspector found no damage, which Jamie states is untrue because the items had already been removed. Her public adjuster, Brandi Carroll, believes the dwelling payment was insufficient given custom cabinetry and other features, and that more than $100,000 in personal property remains unpaid. Brandy has all documents, photos, and estimates. Jamie is seeking legal assistance to recover the underpaid amounts and address Nationwide’s mishandling of the claim.

fields.additionalinformation: Client eported that Erie Insurance denied his hail-damage roof claim despite substantial evidence of damage, including documentation from a major storm on March 15 and multiple roofing professionals confirming the need for replacement. He explained that Erie’s third-party adjuster performed only a brief, inadequate inspection and the insurer refuses to reinspect or assign a different adjuster. Kevin noted that many neighbors received full roof replacements from their insurers after the same storms, causing him further frustration. He has made no repairs, has two repair estimates ranging from about $28,000 to $45,000, and was referred to our firm by public adjuster Brandi Carol after the claim reached a stalemate

wanted to update you on your claim. The adjuster reviewed our photos of the hail damage to your roof but essentially ignored them in an email response.

With your permission, I would like to have one of our attorneys send a demand letter to the insurance carrier. This letter would demand they pay the claim and highlight the obvious hail damage shown in our photo reports.

To proceed, you would need to reach out to the attorney, whom I can introduce you to, and sign a limited letter of representation. This document essentially gives the attorney permission to send letters to the insurance carrier on your behalf. There would be no cost to you for this service, but we need the permissions signed first.

Would it be okay if I introduced you to Attorney Bart Denham in an email so we can get this process moving forward?

fields.where: Gm contractor (Ideal Contracting) and its subcontractors
fields.additionalinformation: In November 2024, an explosion occurred at a GM facility in Michigan that impacted nearby homes. Among the affected homeowners are Brett and Miranda Gohrmann, who are seeking to pursue claims against GM. Although GM dispatched contractors to complete repairs, significant issues remain unresolved, both from the explosion itself and from the work performed by GM’s contractors. The homeowners also have concerns about potential structural damage to the property and possible water supply contamination related to the product used to extinguish the fire caused by the explosion. In addition, they report experiencing emotional distress as a result of the incident.

fields.typeofloss: air handler, air conditioner, insulation, duct work, mold
fields.causeofloss: HVAC issues caused water intrusion into the property and mold subsequently due to improper installation of the A Coil in the HVAC system. Mold has lead to unsafe living conditions and financial hardship.
fields.howdidyounoticethedamage: High humidity alerts on thermostat
fields.additionalinformation:
Nicklous Smith purchased a mobile home from Clayton Homes in Louisa, KY. After installation, the contractor improperly set up the HVAC system without a P-trap, causing humidity issues, standing water, and mold growth.

By July 2025, Nicklous discovered water pooling inside the air handler near the breaker. 2 licensed HVAC technicians confirmed the unit was oversized (3-ton instead of 2.5-ton), leading to moisture buildup, water in the underbelly, and likely mold-contaminated insulation and ductwork.

Nicklous contacted Clayton Homes, HomeFirst (extended warranty), and Kentucky Farm Bureau:

Clayton Homes offered partial repairs (air handler, ducts, insulation) but not full remediation.

HomeFirst is the extended warranty company which denied coverage, claiming it wasn’t a covered defect. Farm Bureau was notified but elected not to file a claim with them, they insisted on getting HomeFirst or Clayton Homes to provide coverage.

DIY mold tests came back positive, though Clayton refused action pending lab confirmation.

No payments or repairs have been made. Nicklous and his wife Lindsey Smith seek legal help to pursue Clayton Homes and others for defective installation, property damage, and mold contamination

fields.howdidyounoticethedamage: after gaining access to the property following the eviction in June. Once inside, they discovered water and mold damage in the kitchen, which led them to bring in a restoration company for further inspection.
fields.additionalinformation:
Client owns a rental property that was occupied by uncooperative tenants during an eviction process when a hailstorm hit. Several neighbouring homes had roofs replaced due to hail damage, but the client couldn’t access the property until after the eviction in June. Once inside, they discovered water and mold damage in the kitchen. A restoration company determined the damage was caused by water intrusion through hail-damaged siding. A roofer and public adjuster later confirmed significant hail damage to the roof, flashing, siding, and gutters.

The client filed a claim with Grange Insurance through their public adjuster. They have continued paying the mortgage during the eviction and claims process but now wish to sell the property. Their concern is whether making repairs out of pocket and selling the home could negatively impact their insurance claim.

fields.additionalinformation: DOL is based on attached "contents" document.  Suit was filed within the year, so SOL is no longer an issue.

We are having issues with State Farm after a leak that resulted in us with a gutted house and we are nearing the 2 year deadline (January 14), we are over $170,000 into repairs and they have paid $68,000 and say that is all it should take to replace the entire interior that was down to subfloor and framing, no wiring, no insulation. We are wanting a tolling agreement due to delays on their end from the start and hoping to get help in recovering something closer to what this has cost us.

Laura Hanson called to discuss significant issues with her homeowner’s insurance claim involving extensive repair costs, living expense disputes, and ongoing delays. She stated the insurer stopped paying for repairs, citing a national average rebuild cost of approximately $180 per square foot, despite no such limitation appearing in her policy and her actual repair costs being nearly three times that amount. Laura emphasized that no major upgrades were made and that the insurer has provided misleading and inconsistent information throughout the claim process.

Laura also reported serious problems with Additional Living Expenses (ALE), including being directed to use expensive Airbnb housing (approximately $10,000 per month) while being initially prohibited from using far less expensive apartment alternatives. She later learned the apartment option should have been allowed. She described repeated delays, including a three-and-a-half-month delay just to receive the correct link to submit personal property claims, raising concerns about missed deadlines. Laura estimates the policy provided approximately $182,000 in dwelling coverage, that she has exceeded that amount, and that the insurer may still owe approximately $70,000, in addition to other disputed expenses. Overall, the family reports being out hundreds of thousands of dollars.

fields.additionalinformation:
Hello,

I have been dealing with the insurance company since my home was surrounded in water and damaged during the February 2025 flood. The damage is substantial, obvious, and legitimate, as evidenced by contractors and even the claims adjuster (multiple times over the phone and in person - off record, of course). Yet, I’ve been met with resistance at every turn.

Upon initial inspection by the claims adjuster on approximately February 21, I received an estimate for damages and then a proof of loss and subsequent check for $3,600.90 (after the deductible). This was to cover damages and cleaning in the crawlspace.

During that initial inspection, the adjuster found that my home had also sustained structural damage. He made the recommendation to go ahead and file an initial claim and then the insurance company would hire a structural engineer to survey the additional damages. He actually stated on several occasions that he personally felt that I would receive policy limit and that m my house could probably be condemned as he didn’t see how it would withstand another flood event due to the significant structural damage, especially to the foundation and pier and weight bearing supports. So, we proceeded with the structural engineer.

The structural engineer’s report made several false claims about pre-existing damage, but he also contradicted his claims multiple times throughout the report. The insurance company only acknowledged the damage claimed to be pre-existing and I was denied any compensation and my claim was closed.

After much conversation and ultimately submitting a formal request, as well as a copy of the engineer’s report with the admission and documentation of damage that was caused by the current flooding marked and noted with a highlighter, the insurance company finally agreed to reopen my claim on June 2, more than 3 months after the flood, and asked that I submit an estimate for repairs from a licensed contractor, which I did.

The estimate to repair only the damage caused by the flooding that is allowable and eligible for compensation, as defined in the flood policy, was $133,688. I was told by the contractor that the cost to repair all damage from the flood would actually be twice that amount and cost more than just tearing down my house and rebuilding. I did not submit that estimate because I understood how the policy was written and any damage caused by earth movement or soil erosion is not covered, as the policy is a single-peril policy that only pays for covered damage due to direct physical loss by or from flood (II.C.14), not as a result of the flood waters moving the foundation and in turn, causing structural damage.

So, I agreed with the adjuster and insurance company to only submit damages caused by direct contact with water, which is what I did. Since that date, I have been met with nothing but stress and aggravation, and have pleaded my case nearly daily to someone in the group of those involved, all to no avail. I understand the flood policy is written with many exclusions as to structural damage, but the damage I am requesting to be compensated for is completely legitimate and meets the requirements of the policy.

Although it seems like a simple, cut and dry claim, I just can’t get anyone to read (or care) enough to understand. Then on June 25, more than 4 months since the flood, I finally received a proof of loss for the structural damage. With estimates for more than $133,000 and a policy limit of $120,000, I was offered an additional $1,281.69 for damages ($4,882.59 total with the initial claim) and was told if I wasn’t satisfied to appeal it.

I have researched and read nearly every appeal decision and memo available on the FEMA website and I’m fairly confident that if I appeal to FEMA, it will simply result in a loss of time and effort on my part, as FEMA simply concurs with the insurance company’s decision in nearly all similar cases. This is a well-known fact. Therefore, I would like to pursue litigation and file suit against the insurer and/or FEMA, if possible, as I see no other reasonable recourse.

The claims adjuster is asking that I sign the proof of loss and assuring me that doing so is not stating that I agree with the amount, nor will it forfeit my right to appeal. However, I have been lied to so many times since this started in February, that I want to make certain before signing.

Also, at the bottom of the Proof of Loss, it states, “I understand that I must submit a Proof of Loss within 60 days of the date of the loss or within any extension of that deadline made in writing by FEMA's Federal Insurance Administrator.”

The date of loss listed on the Proof of Loss is February 15, 2025, well past the 60 day deadline and there is no other date or note of an extension. I have not signed because I’m just not sure if I should or not.

I have all emails, reports, documentation, photos, etc. printed and organized date. I also have everything saved in .pdf and .jpg format and uploaded to my online Google drive for which I can provide a link. Many of the emails are replies, so need to be read from the bottom up, or last page to first, within each dated file.

I am in the Pikeville, KY area, but will be traveling though Lexington this Thursday, July 31 and could bring all printed documents to you and sign any required paperwork if you think I have a case and are willing to accept it.

I appreciate your time and consideration and look forward to hearing from you.

Sincerely,

Eric T. Compton
(606) 616-2978

fields.additionalinformation:
Client reports roof damage likely caused by wind in early March 2025, while she and her husband were in Florida and is disputing Stillwater Insurance’s assignment of the loss date—which increased her deductible and reduced payment—seeking legal help for a potential bad faith insurance claim.

Homeowner Elizabeth Fox experienced roof damage at her Prospect, KY property while she was away in Florida. After returning on May 8, 2025, she discovered a shingle on the ground, and her roofer later confirmed storm damage likely occurred in early March 2025. When she filed a claim with Stillwater Insurance on June 12, 2024, the company recorded the date of loss as May 15–16, 2025, after her deductible had increased from $2,500 to $12,680 on April 21, 2025. Despite a $19,600 roof replacement estimate, Stillwater only issued a $550 payment and closed the claim. Mrs. Fox filed a complaint with the Kentucky Department of Insurance, which partially ruled in her favor, but the dispute over the date of loss and deductible remains unresolved. She seeks legal representation for a potential property damage and insurance bad faith claim.






Elizabeth Fox called to follow up on her ongoing homeowners insurance dispute and stated she is now ready to involve a law firm. The Kentucky Department of Insurance advised her that the remaining issue in her claim is factual in nature, which they cannot resolve.

The claim involves roof damage at her home in Norton Commons (Prospect, KY). Elizabeth and her husband returned from Florida in early May 2025 and noticed a loose shingle on the ground. A roofer inspected the roof on June 12, 2025, confirmed the shingle came from her roof, and identified additional missing shingles. A claim was reported that same day.

At issue is the date of loss. Stillwater Insurance recorded the date as May 15–16, 2025, which placed the loss after a significant deductible increase that went into effect on April 21, 2025. Elizabeth disputes this and states she reported that the damage occurred before May 8, 2025, when they returned home. She believes the insurer intentionally pushed the date forward to apply the higher deductible.

Stillwater initially denied the claim due to the deductible exceeding their damage estimate. Elizabeth’s roofer determined the shingles could not be reasonably matched, which under Kentucky law requires full roof replacement. After Elizabeth filed a complaint with the Kentucky Department of Insurance, Stillwater ultimately agreed to replace the roof but calculated payment in a way that left Elizabeth with only about $500 after applying the increased deductible to a roughly $19,000 roof replacement. She has not cashed the check.

projectName: Fox, Elizabeth et al. v. Stillwater

fields.additionalinformation:
Michael Gentry experienced a major water loss on June 8, 2024, when a pipe burst in his home, causing significant flooding. He filed a homeowner’s insurance claim with Home Site Insurance.
The mitigation company, ServiceMaster, allegedly performed poor work that left moisture in the HVAC system, leading to additional rust and damage throughout the home.

Mr. Gentry filed a claim with Home Site, but he reports receiving a low settlement offer and facing numerous delays. The initial payment was held by the mortgage company for 45 days before he could access any funds. Over the past year and a half, he has been bounced between more than eight different adjusters, each requesting duplicate documentation. Home Site has paid approximately $114,000 toward repairs, but they are now refusing to release additional funds until Mr. Gentry provides further proof of how all prior payments were spent.

The home remains unfinished, with the kitchen and master bathroom still needing repairs estimated at $30,000–$40,000. Mr. Gentry has also exceeded his temporary housing coverage since February 2025 and is now more than $40,000 out of pocket. He believes the insurer is acting in bad faith by delaying the process and forcing him to repeatedly resubmit information.

Mr. Gentry would like to pursue legal action or otherwise obtain guidance on his options. He mentioned being told that he may be unable to sue until the claim is formally denied and that his policy may include a one-year limitation period. He is also concerned about ServiceMaster’s potential liability for poor mitigation work. I was informed by the agent handling the case on November 13th that they are sending me a proof of loss document and I have 60 days to fill it out. I feel like I'm being accused of something and that they're just turning everything around on me. Adding stress and damage to what has already been one of the most uncomfortable situations I've ever dealt with in my life. This was worse than my divorce. It has become so straining that we are literally at the point of trying to just sell the home and get out of it it is just left a bad taste in our mouth that I don't believe we can recover from.

His insurance company refusing to fix his roof. Get or done roofing company did an assessment revealing that it was due to rain/hail damage, but the insurance adjuster told him it was lack of maintenance.

client’s home experienced flooding after a flash storm caused heavy rain that overwhelmed and eroded the soil around their egress window. Water filled the window well, broke the glass, and poured into the basement, causing extensive water damage to the carpet and drywall. Mitigation services removed two feet of drywall, but repairs have not yet been completed as the client is still seeking estimates, including from the original builder. The insurance company, National General, denied the claim on the basis of “ground water,” which the client does not fully understand.

Their son was downstairs during the storm, saw water coming in and called for them. When the client went downstairs, they saw that the window had filled with water, the glass broke, and storm water was flooding into the basement.

fields.additionalinformation:
In a flash flood on June 28, in a matter of 30 minutes water was 6 feet deep in my yard and 5 of my neighbors yards. Another neighbor lost her entire finished basement (where she lived) due to the same flood and is receiving no help with repairs. The drainage ditch next to my house filled up over 6 feet and crossed the street next to my house, at the same time it breached the water retention wall around my walk out basement, busted down the door, and filled my house with 8.5 feet of water in less than 10 minutes. I do not live in a flood zone or near any water (pond, river, lake etc). Our house is unlivable as the breaker box was fully submerged, our bedroom and son’s bedroom were full to the ceiling of water for over 24 hours and the AC was fully submerged in water and no longer works. At the time this occurred, our contractor who finished our basement 2 years ago watched Hopkinsville Water Environment Authority
change out a quarry pump at the end of my road. They are still denying responsibility. The city is also denying any responsibility despite that they have no record of maintenance on storm water drains in the city (they also have no maps) and in a city council meeting in July the storm water director verbalized that they did not maintain the North Drive water basin in the past 20 years (less than a mile from affected area). 

This is the number for Brandy Stallins. She and her four or five neighbors have a potential claim for property damage against, we think, the water authority, company, in Hopkinsville.
I know property damage usually isn’t your thing, but there’s definitely in excess of six figures worth of damage amongst the neighbors, and Brandy, at least, is willing to sign a contingent contract.
The distance is what’s keeping me from taking the case.
You have permission to call her Direct, and she is waiting to talk to you. Good luck!

Roof damage due to water damage

It started the first week of June when we had heavy rains at least 3 times a week for the month of June. My ceiling in my dining room started to leak and chip away. I contacted my insurance and they had someone to inspect. The inspector didn’t find anything wrong. I had a roofing company to inspect my roof and the damages inside my home and sent photos to my insurance company. The insurance company had the roofing inspector to return an additional two times for more photos and markers. Then the insurance company decided it’s not a roof repair but an installation issue.staring it’s not properly ventilated and that was moisture condensed. Which is not true because every time it’s heavy rain I’m experiencing the same issues and I’m afraid it’s going to be a hole in my ceiling soon. My insurance company then sent a check for $1261.52 in July to have a contractor to repair my ceiling and not the roof.


Client reported roof and interior water damage that occurred in early June 2025 while she was out of town. When she returned, parts of her dining room ceiling had collapsed, and rainwater was leaking into the home. Her insurer, HomeSite, had two contractors inspect the roof—one said it was intact, while another noted it was over 20 years old and severely deteriorated. Despite this, HomeSite denied roof coverage, claiming the issue was due to condensation and lack of ventilation, not storm damage. The company issued a small payment of about $1,260 for interior drywall and paint repairs. No repairs have been completed yet because she cannot find a contractor. Ms. Crumble believes the damage is roof-related and is seeking legal assistance to challenge the denial and obtain full coverage for repairs.

Client experienced a pipe burst at his rental property on December 23, 2023 in Richmond, Kentucky. At the time, he held a landlord/property-manager policy with Shelter Insurance, but was told burst-pipe damage wasn’t covered, so he arranged remediation himself. A technician brought in dryers and began drying the walls, the carpet was removed, new baseboards installed, and hardwood flooring replaced. In September 2024, he noticed black residue emerging from HVAC vents. An independent restoration professional confirmed water behind the walls, linking the issue back to the earlier event. He submitted a claim but the adjuster denied it, citing that the original damage occurred before his policy began. No estimate or payment was provided.

I have another Indiana claim file for your review. This is Kelly and Paul Szymanski.  Kelly is the Pastor over The Church of God of Prophecy.  The date of loss is 07/15/2024 where a bad storm hit the property and knocked a tree over onto the church.  The roof was damaged along with the side of the building.  There was also interior water damage to the ceiling in the sanctuary.We've taken the claim as far as we can.  The local agent had stopped by to go over a review with the clients for renewal.  At that time, Mitch thought he might be able to help.  The desk adjuster then decided to set up an engineer inspection in August.  We've finally received a copy of the engineer report on 10/08/2025 with no change to the stance the carrier is taking.

The PSA estimate is for $87,383.09. The Carrier's estimate is $9,312.89 RCV value.  The client had to move forward with repairs last week because of this dragging out for so long.  The roofer called us out to take pictures to document to show that the sheathing is in no shape to be reused.

fields.additionalinformation:
Homeowner’s insurance claim – property damage from April 2024 storms (lightning, wind, and water intrusion). Underpayment and mishandling of an insurance claim.

Client is seeking legal assistance regarding an unresolved homeowner’s insurance claim with State Farm following severe storms in early April 2024 that caused lightning, wind, and water damage to her home and garage. The garage, which was used for storage, contained a significant amount of personal property valued at approximately $72,000, including items from her former boutique business and important legal documents. Despite extensive damage, State Farm has only made partial payments totaling about $15,000 and has provided inconsistent explanations for why much of her property was not covered. The company delayed assigning an adjuster until late April and did not inspect the property until mid-May, by which time the damage had worsened. Tiffany reports that she has dealt with multiple adjusters, conflicting information, and coverage errors, such as payments marked for repairs that were never completed. She believes State Farm failed to properly apply the “storm-created opening” clause in her policy and did not honor a verbal assurance made by a section manager in June that her claim would be fully paid. Tiffany estimates her total losses at around $100,000 to $130,000 and is now seeking legal help to recover the remaining unpaid amounts for her property, electrical work, and home repairs.

Goes by Murdy 

Murdy wishes to look into his options of bringing litigation against Mercury Insurance for a water loss that occurred at his residence on 31 July 2024.

I was introduced to Mr. Salah by a hygienist and performed a preliminary inspection of the property, and ultimately signed him to a PA contract on 24 Oct 2025.  Subsequently, I was unable to do a thorough investigation and, for various reasons, released Mr, Salah from his obligation on 24 Jan 2025 as I wasn't able to perform my duties to the best of my ability.

Mr. Salah reached out around 29 July 2025 and asked if I may be able to help him again, as he and his contractor were not able to make any headway on his claim.  I agreed, I performed an investigation as best as I could because mitigation and repairs had already been completed on his property.

I was able to reach a verbal settlement offer from Mercury, and Mr; Salah doesn't feel indemnified and wants to pursue litigation.

fields.where: partially completed repairs on his own. He has nearly finished repairing the bathrooms and recently started working on the basement. The home remains partially unusable, and much of the basement and affected areas are still under repair.
fields.additionalinformation:
Our house was devastated by a plumbing crisis on 11/19/24. Liberty Mutual dragged their feet all year, eventually not paying enough to cover expenses. Liberty changed reps over ten times, went back on their word multiple times. Work is still not done almost a year later. Family has had no access to a third of our home, multiple health issues and financial strain over that time.

Client experienced a severe sewage backup at his home that originated from an overflow in the master bathroom and caused extensive damage throughout the basement, primary bathroom, and walk-in closet. The sewage included hazardous materials, leading to mold growth and rendering much of the home uninhabitable. Multiple contractors estimated repairs between $75,000 and $120,000, but his insurance provider, Liberty Mutual, initially paid only about $43,000 and repeatedly delayed and mishandled the claim. Jacob and his family were displaced for over three weeks, staying in hotels and an Airbnb, and experienced health issues including pneumonia and persistent coughing due to exposure and poor living conditions. Despite repeated disputes and delays, Jacob ultimately began repairs out of necessity, but the home remains partially unusable

Jacob received multiple contractor estimates for the total damages, which ranged between $75,000 and $120,000.

fields.causeofloss: Brandon’s ex-girlfriend and her new partner, who were living in the home at the time, intentionally damaged the property prior to vacating. Damage included flooding and the removal of the hot water heater, which was later ripped out again after the claim was initially filed.
fields.Insurance Company Name: American Family Mutual Insurance Company, S.I.
fields.additionalinformation:
The loss occurred around October 22, 2025, when Brandon’s ex-girlfriend and her new partner, who were living in the home at the time, intentionally damaged the property prior to vacating. Damage included flooding and the removal of the hot water heater, which was later ripped out again after the claim was initially filed.

The insurance carrier, HomeLight, inspected the property shortly after the claim was submitted and initially indicated no issues. However, after months of inactivity and lack of communication, Brandon filed a Department of Insurance complaint, which prompted contact from a supervisor.

The carrier has since shifted denial reasons multiple times, ultimately citing a vacancy exclusion, despite Brandon having proof the property was occupied at the time of loss. The adjuster has stated a denial letter was sent but has refused to confirm the mailing address, date sent, or provide proof of delivery, raising concerns it may have been sent to the damaged Kentucky property instead of Brandon’s Michigan address.

Estimated damages are approximately $50,000, though no formal repair estimate has been completed yet. Brandon reports extensive documentation and correspondence supporting his position and was advised to email all records to the firm for attorney review.

fields.causeofloss: water damage caused by an attic window A/C unit discharging water
fields.areasofdamagepleaselistallareasofd: Main level living room and second floor office
fields.howdidyounoticethedamage: Saw water discharge from AC unit and water soaking through the attic floor
fields.additionalinformation:
Dakota Smith called Denham Property & Injury Law Firm seeking a consultation regarding a potential bad-faith homeowners insurance claim. He explained that after filing a claim on September 25, 2025, for water damage caused by an attic window A/C unit discharging water, his insurance company denied the claim despite having received professional reports from Servpro and an HVAC technician confirming the source of the damage. The adjuster spent only about 20 minutes inspecting the property, performed no testing, and was caught on security footage admitting uncertainty, yet still issued a denial without citing policy language. After Dakota’s family attorney intervened, the insurer reopened the claim and is now sending an engineer for reinspection. No repairs have been made, no payments issued, and Servpro withheld an estimate due to potential asbestos in attic tiles.


Estimate cost of repairs $15,000 - $20,000

fields.casedescription: Estate of G. Wilson v. Westfield Insurance

projectName: Estate of G. Wilson v. Westfield Insurance

fields.additionalinformation:
Eliza spoke with Britney, who is assisting her mother, Misty Keys, regarding a denied State Farm homeowners insurance claim for water damage at 482 Woodland Street, Dallas, GA 30157. Britney explained that her mother has cognitive impairments and has struggled to manage the claim following significant family trauma, prompting Britney to step in and pursue power of attorney.

The claim involves a leak related to an ice maker line, which was discovered after drywall was removed. A plumber inspected the property, confirmed no additional leaks, and reportedly told the adjuster no further information was needed. Despite this, State Farm denied the claim twice, citing alleged conflicts in the plumbing report and characterizing the damage as pre-existing or the home as a rental—both of which Britney disputes.

Misty has been displaced for over two months and is currently living in a camper in the driveway due to the home being uninhabitable. There are ongoing issues with incorrect policy information, including an outdated primary residence, the policy still being tied to Misty’s deceased husband, and incorrect contact details, which has prevented access to policy documents and claim correspondence.

Britney has sent multiple unanswered emails to State Farm and is seeking assistance due to lack of communication and clarity. Eliza confirmed contact information, requested all prior correspondence and documentation, and advised she would review the matter with an attorney and follow up with next steps by the end of the day or the following day.

fields.additionalinformation:
Caller said a roofing claim was denied by his insurance company. The damage was done by wind and hail. He had two roofing companies take a look at his roof. Caller said the Insurance inspector used the date of April 25, 2025, because that was the date the tornado came through. He was not hit by the tornado, however, there was a lot of wind. But caller is not sure when the damage occurred.

What type of matter are you calling about? Roof damage claim

Date of Loss/Damage: Unsure

What City/State are you located in? Louisville, KY

How did you hear about us?: Google search



In late summer/early fall, a roofer inspecting a neighbor’s roof briefly inspected Jeff’s roof and noted possible wind and hail damage.

A second roofing company (Unisource) conducted a full inspection, took photos, and stated there was sufficient damage to warrant a roof replacement.

Jeff filed an insurance claim but did not know the exact date of loss, as the damage appeared cumulative over time.

Insurance sent Knight Solutions (ladder assist), which found minimal damage and attributed issues to improper installation.

Claim was denied shortly after.


30,000-40,000 estimate cost of damages

fields.areasofdamagepleaselistallareasofd: Water Damage - Fireplace, Upstairs Bedrooms, Cabinets next to fireplace.
fields.howdidyounoticethedamage: Discovered water marks around the fireplace crown molding. Inspected other areas and discovered moisture in upstairs bedrooms along with the presence of mold.
fields.additionalinformation:
Water leak at chimney flashing (Lexington Blue replaced roof in November 2023)
My insurance agent suggested having an independent roofer look at the roof. Determined we had nearly $3000 in deficient detailing all over the roof from Lexington Blue at multiple locations. We have a before and after repair report. May be something with the original roofer’s insurance company?
Masonry Chimney may also have issues. Mason has torn down and rebuilt first 6-7’ of chimney to roof line. We had the chimney tuckpointed 5-6 years ago. Barn Hill Chimney has rebuilt the crown and reflash the step flashing at the chimney today.
Upon demolition it was discovered the previous owner of the home had made the same significant repair at the same location and did not disclose. (Significant structural repairs). We have the disclosure statement from when we purchased the home. It was June of 2015
Insulation of the HVAC refrigerant line in the exterior wall cavity had degraded since the house was constructed and the exposed copper line had been condensing inside the warm exterior cavity undetectable.
Homeowners Insurance – Denied claim
 

I am not suggesting tackling all of this….really looking to see if there is a possibility for any restitution. The significant impact it has had on my wife’s health has been extreme (misdiagnosed with MS, she has had chronic insomnia and nigh seizures) and a repair that is approaching $70k today, without a clear line of what it will end up costing is a very hard thing to swallow. I am not sure why insurance can deny a claim like this which was reported within days of discovering there was an issue.

fields.additionalinformation:
My home burned down and State Farm mishandled the claim from the beginning—wrong measurements, missing materials, Xactimate-only pricing, and substantial underpayment. They are only redoing the claim because I confronted them with the errors. I am seeking help from Denham Law for a Kentucky bad-faith insurance action.

Jason reports a total home loss due to fire and believes State Farm is severely underpaying and mishandling his claim. He has received payments of approximately $74,000 (ALE/housing), $181k+ (personal property), and $212,000 (dwelling). His main dispute is with the dwelling rebuild amount, which he states is nowhere near sufficient. Based on his own construction background (22 years) and a detailed estimate he generated from chat gpt, he believes the true rebuild cost is around $400,000.

State Farm is only using Xactimate pricing and not real Kentucky labor/material costs.

They depreciated items that should not be depreciated under KY law (e.g., HVAC by 80%).

They reduced his dwelling coverage based on a prior roof claim, even though he replaced the roof himself.

He states they undervalued the dwelling by ~$80,000 below the minimum required under his policy.

He reports unresponsiveness, being blocked from emailing his adjuster, and having to communicate through his local agent.

He has filed a complaint with the KY Department of Insurance.

I am requesting representation regarding a first-party boat hull insurance dispute with
Progressive involving my vessel, a 2006 Rinker 360 (“Knot on Call”), Claim No. 25-279938808
(loss date: September 14, 2025; Tennessee).
Progressive maintains a “pre-existing/causation” denial posture and has repeatedly refused to
provide the surveys/photos it cites as support. I have assembled a concise intake packet for
quick review.

fields.typeofloss: Hail Damage to Roof and various fixtures
fields.causeofloss: Hail Damage to Roof and various fixtures
fields.where: Curtis is having roof replaced today (10/14) due to ongoing leaks.
fields.additionalinformation:
I had a leak in April 2025 and called a roofer to repair it.  I was told the roof had hail damage and wasn't repairable.  I filed a claim with my Insurance company who then denied replacing my roof because the damage wasn't significant, yet they paid for hail damage to my skylight, gutters and roof vents.  I called two other roofing companies who also stated the roof had hail damage and needed replacement.  I wrote the KY Dept. of Insurance who investigated but back that no laws were broken and that they do not regulate the opinion of an insurance company.  The roofers are here today replacing my roof and skylight at a cost of $32,000.


Curtis Foote, of Crestwood, KY, filed a homeowner’s claim with Erie Insurance in April 2025 after a March–April 2025 storm caused roof leaks and hail damage. His roofer and two additional companies confirmed significant hail damage requiring full roof replacement.

Erie’s adjuster acknowledged some damage but approved only $4,858.18 for minor repairs (vents, skylight, gutters, screens) and denied roof replacement. Curtis did not deposit the check. Erie later sent an engineer who supported their denial, despite multiple contractors finding hail damage.

Curtis filed a complaint with the Kentucky Insurance Commissioner, who found no regulatory violations. He has since replaced the roof at his own cost (~$32,000) and believes Erie’s actions may constitute bad faith.
Wants to go after Erie Insurance for wrongfully denying and undervaluing his hail damage claim

Caller states that another person drive into her home and would like to pursue a lawsuit. Believes over $100,000 in damage - knocked out structure of her home. Driver does not have enough insurance to coverage the damage. Hit a car inside of her garage and the neighbor's home as well. Has photographs. Is displaced at the moment and is staying in a hotel at the moment. Driver only had 50k in property damage coverage. HOA is working on their end. Engineers are looking into it. Caller personal Insurance is going to cover rebuild of her unit. Engineering still needs to clear that she can return home before she can get further estimates.

A client discusses their problematic home restoration experience with an injury law firm representative, Andrew. The client, identified as (859), describes extensive water damage and mold issues following a 3500-gallon flood, and expresses dissatisfaction with the restoration company, Paul Davis, and their insurance company, USAA, for poor service and lack of communication. Despite multiple attempts to resolve the issue, the client feels unheard and frustrated, particularly with the handling of mold and property damage. They are reluctant to pay for services not satisfactorily completed.


Stephanie is seeking representation related to a complex property damage and insurance bad-faith dispute involving her primary residence and resulting loss of her home investment. She reports a prolonged and escalating breakdown in how her claim was handled, which she believes constitutes insurance bad faith and potentially improper conduct by multiple involved parties, including the insurer and associated or “preferred” vendors.

Stephanie stated that she timely reported the loss and has consistently cooperated by providing extensive documentation, records, communications, and supporting materials. Despite this, she alleges the insurer and related entities have repeatedly delayed, deflected responsibility, and failed to resolve the claim, resulting in worsening property conditions and significant financial loss. She indicated that rather than progressing toward repair or payment, the situation has continued to deteriorate over time.

She described a pattern in which she was asked for additional information repeatedly, complied each time, and was then met with further requests or inaction, creating a cycle of delay. Stephanie believes this conduct was intentional and designed to wear her down or cause her to miss critical deadlines. She specifically referenced looming deadlines that now place her rights at risk if immediate legal action is not taken.

Stephanie reports that the property issues ultimately resulted in her losing her entire home investment, causing substantial financial harm and emotional distress. She believes the insurer failed to properly investigate the claim, failed to act in good faith, and failed to fairly evaluate coverage. She also expressed concerns that third parties involved in the claim process, including vendors connected to the insurer, contributed to or exacerbated the damage and delays.

fields.causeofloss: water damage to his home caused by a solar panel installation
fields.Mortgage Company: SWBC Mortgage Corp ISAOA/ATIMA C/O CENTRAL LOAN ADMINISTRATION AND REPORTING
fields.additionalinformation:
Michael Crump contacted the firm regarding ongoing water damage to his home caused by a solar panel installation completed around November 2023. The damage began leaking around January 2024, shortly after installation. The property is located at 46 Honeysuckle Ridge, Barbourville, KY 40906.

Michael reports repeated attempts to have the solar company (Solgan Solar) return to repair the damage, but despite scheduling appointments and taking time off work, the company repeatedly fails to show up or follow through. As a result, the water intrusion has continued to worsen and is now causing significant interior damage, including floor buckling, damage in the bathroom and utility room, and water intrusion spreading toward the center of the home. He also reports difficulty accessing his attic due to the extent of the damage.

Michael’s homeowners insurance (State Farm) declined coverage, stating the damage is related to the solar panel installation. He has not received any repair estimates and is increasingly concerned as the condition of his previously well-maintained home continues to deteriorate.

Timothy from Day Adjusting and Consulting contacts Olivia at Denta Law Firm about a State Farm claim for Rob Martin, a roofing contractor in Owensboro. The building's roof was damaged by a hail storm, and the insurance is denying the claim due to ongoing water damage, as per an engineer's report. They plan to email all relevant documents and suggest a fee reduction for Rob if they sign up with them. Olivia agrees to facilitate this and suggests setting up an email chain for communication.

Maureen Bucko called regarding a potential property damage claim connected to a class action. She reported a severe hail and windstorm on July 4, 2025, affecting her area near Johnson City / Binghamton, NY. The storm included golf-ball–sized hail, high winds, and heavy rain, causing damage to her roof, Tudor-style siding, and back deck, and she is now experiencing water intrusion on one side of the home during rain and wind.

A contractor inspected the property, documented damage throughout the exterior and roof, and contacted Nationwide on her behalf. Nationwide denied the claim, stating the Tudor siding was not a proper building material and that the damage was not consistent with hail in her area. Maureen strongly disagrees, stating she personally experienced the storm and observed hail damage firsthand.
